item.title: Why weed is illegal
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Greg the Xeno:

I think its really illegal because its easy to grow and the government couldn’t tax it if we home grew it (even though most people do already).

As already said, not decriminalizing it because it can be grown at home is a bad argument. Growing anything takes a long time, and in this case, it takes skill and knowledge to grow a successful plant. You can’t simply chuck it in a pot out in the back garden like you do with tomatos, or something similar.

Besides, tobacco can be grown at home(which is probably healthier than buying it, due to no chemicals being added), alcohol can be distilled at home etc. All it being illegal does is make it more profitable for growers and dealers, and more harmful to potential buyers, jme linked to a video a while back, in which one key argument is without quality control on things like this, any random crap can be added to it to bulk up the weight so dealers can get more money, often not caring about the consequences.

Not too long back, lead was/is being added to some cannabis in Leipzig, Germany.

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:9, topic:269469”]while Weed Smokers can lash out at people.
Its like going over the drunk-drive limit; you are temperarly anaware of your surroundings but ok later.[/quote]

Proof of this? I’d say I’m a pretty calm, average tempered human, and I’ve never “lashed out” at anyone, or lost self-awareness. If anything, I’d say such symptoms are more likely from excessive alcohol than cannabis.

really interesting read on why marijuana is illegal. A lot of people are misinformed (including myself) about why it is illegal, and this should shed some light. Found on Digg.
http://ronebreak.com/2009/02/08/why-marijuana-is-illegal/

Also interesting:

ncbi.nlm.nih.gov

The influence of substance use on adolescent brain development.

LM Squeglia, J Jacobus and SF Tapert, Clinical EEG and neuroscience, Jan 2009

Adolescence is a unique period in neurodevelopment. Alcohol and marijuana use are common. Recent research has indicated that adolescent substance users show abnormalities on measures of brain functioning, which is linked to changes in neurocognition over time. Abnormalities have been seen in brain structure volume, white matter quality, and activation to cognitive tasks, even in youth with as little as 1-2 years of heavy drinking and consumption levels of 20 drinks per month, especially if > 4-5 drinks are consumed on a single occasion. Heavy marijuana users show some subtle anomalies too, but generally not the same degree of divergence from demographically similar non-using adolescents. This article reviews the extant literature on neurocognition, brain structure, and brain function in adolescent substance users with an emphasis on the most commonly used substances, and in the context of ongoing neuromaturational processes. Methodological and treatment implications are provided.
